data.title: Famous Deaths on July 12
data.meta_description: Famous deaths for the 12th of July. See which celebrities, historical figures, scientists and criminals died throughout history on July 12.
data.text:
Bertrada of Laon, Frankish queen sometimes referred to as "Bertha Broadfoot", and mother of Charlemange the Great, dies

Johannes Gualbertus, Italian monk/saint, dies

Jean de Gerson, French theologian (Theologica mystic), dies at 65

Ashikaga Yoshinori, Japanese shōgun (1429-41), assassinated during an evening play by the Akamatsu family at 48

Jack Cade who led a revolt against English King Henry VI is captured and mortally wounded in Sussex. His head later erected on a pole on London Bridge.

Erasmus

Dutch humanist and theologian (The Praise of Folly), dies at 69

Maria Manuela van Portugal, niece of Spanish King Philip II, dies

Renée of France, duchess of Ferrara and daughter of French King Louis XII, dies at 63

Steven Borough, English explorer, dies at 58

Simon Besler, German composer, dies at 49

Henry Casimir I, count of Nassau-Dietz, dies

Stefano della Bella, Italian printmaker (b. 1610)

Jean Picard, French astronomer, dies at 61

John Ashby, English admiral

William of Nassau de Zuylenstein, Earl of Rochford, Dutch soldier and diplomat, dies

Richard Cromwell

Lord Protector of the Commonwealth of England, Scotland and Ireland (1658-59), dies at 85

Evaristo Felice dall'Abaco, Italian cellist and composer, dies on 67th birthday

Charles de la Boische, Marquis de Beauharnois, Governor of New France

Johann Joachim Quantz, German royal flautist and composer, dies at 76

Alexander Hamilton

US Founding Father and 1st Secretary of the Treasury (1789-95), killed by Vice President Aaron Burr in pistol duel near Weehawken at 49

William Howe

5th Viscount Howe, British military leader (commander of British forces in the American Revolutionary War), dies at 84

David Douglas, Scottish botanist (Douglas fir), dies from falling in to a pit trap while surveying Mauna Kea in Hawaiʻi at 35

Charles-Louis Panckoucke, French publisher, dies at 63

Henrik Wergeland, Norwegian poet (Creation, Humanity, and Messiah) and author, dies at 37

Dolley Madison, American 4th First Lady Of The United States (1809-17) as wife of President James Madison, dies at 81 [1]

Robert Stevenson, Scottish civil engineer (Bell Rock Lighthouse, Scotland), dies at 78

Fritz Reuter, German novelist, dies at 63

Alfred Pease, American composer, dies at 44

Hermann Zopff, German composer, dies at 57

Ferdinand Berthier, French deaf educator (founder of the Société Centrale des Sourds-muets), dies at 82

Alexander Cartwright

American Baseball HOF pioneer (recognised as inventor of modern baseball, "father of baseball"), dies at 72

Cyrus West Field, American financier noted for success of 1st transatlantic cable, dies at 72

Félix Godefroid, Belgian harpist and composer, dies at 78

Paul Voulet, French captain/mass murderer in Senegal, dies

Mauritius Adriaan de Savornin Lohman, Dutch Governor of Suriname (1889-91), dies at 67

Pieter Caland, Dutch hydraulic engineer (New Waterway), dies at 74

Henrique Alves de Mesquita, Brazilian composer, conductor and educator, dies at 70

Charles Rolls

British aviator and auto manufacturer who co-founded Rolls Royce, dies in a place crash at 32, the 1st British person to do so

François Fournier, Swiss-French postage stamp forger, dies at 71

Dragutin Lerman, Croatian explorer, dies at 54

1918 William McComb, American Brigadier General (Confederate Army), dies at 89

Charles Wood, Irish composer, dies at 40

Gertrude Bell

British archaeologist (Desert & The Sown), dies at 57

Robert Henri, American painter (The Eight) and leader of Ashcan school of painting, dies at 63

Willem H. Drucker, Dutch lawyer, dies at 45

Ole Evinrude, Norwegian-American industrialist and inventor (outboard marine engine), dies at 57

Alfred Dreyfus

French Jewish artillery officer (Dreyfus Affair), dies at 75

Boris Galerkin, Russian mathematician (b. 1871)

1945 Wolfram von Richthofen, German-Nazi military officer (fighter pilot - WWI; Chief of Staff -Spanish civil war; Luftwaffe field marshal - WWII), dies as a prisoner of war in an army hospital of a brain tumor at 49

Ray Stannard Baker, American journalist (Puliter Prize 1940), dies at 76

Jimmie Lunceford, American swing jazz saxophonist and bandleader (Rhythm Is Our Business; For Dancers Only), dies of a heart attack at 45 [1] [2]

Douglas Hyde, first President of Ireland (b. 1860)

Elsie de Wolfe, American socialite and interior decorator (b. 1865)

Joseph Jongen, Belgian organist and composer (Symphonie concertante, Op. 81), dies at 79 [1]

Maurice Lippens, Belgian governor of Congo (1921-23), dies at 80

Mazo de la Roche, Canadian author (b. 1879)

Roger Wolfe Kahn, American bandleader ("I'm Sitting On Top Of The World"), and aviator, dies of a heart attack at 54

William Solomon, South African cricketer (Test 1898-99), dies

D. T. Suzuki, Zen Japanese-American Buddhist scholar, dies in Tokyo, Japan at 96

Lon Chaney Jr [Creighton Tull Chaney], American actor (Of Mice and Men; The Wolfman), dies of heart failure at 67

Georg Annenkov, Russian-French artist and stage and film set designer ('The Mutiny of the Machines'), dies at 84

Carl Snavely, American College Football Hall of Fame coach (Bucknell, North Carolina, Cornell 180–96–16), dies at 80

Ted Mack, American TV host (The Original Amateur Hour), dies at 72

Ed Holmes, actor (Growing Paynes, Once Upon a Tune), dies at 66

1977 Frantisek Suchy, Czech oboist and composer (Moravian Wind Quintet), dies at 75

Kalervo Tuukkanen, Finnish composer, dies at 69

1979 Minnie Ripperton [Andrea Davis], American pop, R&B, and disco singer-songwriter ("Lovin' You"), dies of breast cancer at 31

John W Davis, President (WV State college), dies at 92

Ben Seijes, historian (WWII), dies at 73

1981 Merrill Ellis, American classical and experimental music composer, and performer (Kaleidoscope; Mutations), dies at 64

Kenneth More, British actor (39 Steps, Doctor in the House), dies of Parkinson's disease at 67

Chris Wood, British rock saxophone and flute player (Traffic; Ginger Baker's Air Force, Jimi Hendrix), dies of pneumonia at 39

1983 Edwin Denby, American dance critic and poet (Snoring in N, Horse Eats Hat), dies at 80

Joshua Logan, Broadway producer (South Pacific), dies at 79 of palsy

1988 Julian Trevelyan, English Surrealist painter and collage maker, dies at 78

1988 Raymond W Goldsmith, US economist, dies at 83

Sidney Hook, American philosopher (The Paradoxes of Freedom), dies at 86

João Saldanha, Brazilian journalist and football manager (Brazil 1969-70), dies at 73

1990 Richard R Briggs, dies after short illness at 71

Carla van Neste, Belgian classical violinist (Trio Reine Elisabeth), dies at 78

1992 Reginald Beck, English film editor (Robbery, Accident, Boom), dies

Dan Eldon, British-Kenyan photojournalist, killed in Somalia while working for Reuters at 22

1993 Gusti Huber, Austrian American actress, (The Diary of Anne Frank), dies of heart failure at 78

1993 Lily van Lugt Melsert, Dutch actress (Tomorrow Will Be Better), dies at 91

David Malcolm Lewis, English historian, expert in Greek Epigraphy, dies at 56

1994 Henk Terlingen, Dutch radio and TV host (Sport in Image), dies at 52

1994 James Bysse Joll, British historian, dies at 76

Alan David Marks, American concert pianist, dies of cancer at 49

1995 Earl Coleman, American jazz singer, dies of cardiac arrest at 69

1995 Ernie Furtado, American jazz double-bassist, dies at 72

1995 Michael Clegg, English naturalist and TV presenter (Clegg's People), dies at 62

(Andrew) Rodger Waterson, Scottish zoologist, specializing in malacology (mollusks) and entomology (insects), dies at 84

1996 Gottfried von Einem, Austrian composer, mainly of opera (Der Prozeß - The Trial), dies at 78

1996 John Boon, English publisher (MiIls and Boon), dies at 79

1996 John Chancellor, American journalist and news anchor (Voice Of America, 1965-67; NBC Nightly News, 1970-82), dies at 68

1996 Jonathan Melvoin, American funk-rock keyboardist (Prince; Smashing Pumpkins, 1995-96), dies of a heroin overdose at 34

1996 Nazar Mohammad, Pakistani cricket batsman (5 Tests, 1 x 100 Pakistan's 1st centurion), dies at 75

Jimmy Driftwood, American folk songwriter and musician, dies at 91

1998 Serge Lemoyne, French Canadian artist (b. 1941)

Bill Flett, Canadian NHL and WHA hockey forward, 1967-80 (Stanley Cup, 1974, 1975 - Philadelphia Flyers, and 3 other teams), dies of liver failure at 55

1999 Bill Owen [William Owen Rowbotham], British actor (Last of the Summer Wine, Not So Dusty), dies from pancreatic cancer at 85

Charles Merritt, Canadian Army officer and recipient of the Victoria Cross during World War II, dies at 98

2000 Merrill Bradshaw, American composer, and music professor (Brigham Young, 1957-94), dies at 71

Edward Lee Howard

American CIA Case Officer and alleged Soviet spy who defected to the Soviet Union in 1985, dies at 50 after breaking his neck during a fall

(Bennett) "Benny" Carter, American Grammy Award-winning jazz saxophonist, clarinetist, trumpeter, arranger, composer ("Harlem Renaissance Suite"), and bandleader, dies at 93

Betty Oliphant, co-founder of National Ballet of Canada (b. 1918)

2004 Jean Ruth Adams, American entomologist (insect pathogens and viruses), dies at 75 or 76

John King, Baron King of Wartnaby, British businessman and CEO of British Airways after its privatization, dies at 87

Hubert Lampo, Flemish writer and essayist (The Coming of Joachim Stiller), dies at 85

Mr. Butch, Iconic Boston street figure (b. 1951)

2007 Robert Burås, Norwegian rock guitarist (Madrugada; My Midnight Creeps), dies at 31

2007 Stan Zemanek, Australian radio personality (b.1947)

Bobby Murcer, American baseball outfielder (5-time MLB All Star), dies of brain cancer at 62

2008 Tony Snow, former speechwriter for Presidents George H. W. Bush and press secretary for George W. Bush, dies of colon and liver cancer at 53

Donald MacCormick, British broadcaster, dies at 70

2009 Simon Vinkenoog, Dutch writer and poet, dies at 80

Buff Cobb [Patrizia Cobb Chapman], American actress and TV personality (Masquerade Party), dies at 82

2010 Harvey Pekar, American comic book writer (American Splendor), dies at 70

2010 James P. Hogan, British sci-fi author (Giants' Star), dies at 69

2010 Paulo Moura, Brazilian jazz and swing clarinetist and saxophonist, dies at 77

David Carr, British rock keyboardist (The Fortunes, 1963-68 - "You've Got Your Troubles"; "Here It Comes Again"), dies at 67

2011 Sam Denoff, American screenwriter (The Dick Van Dyke Show) and television producer (That Girl), dies from complications of Alzheimer's disease at 83 [1]

2011 Sherwood Schwartz, American television screenwriter and producer (The Brady Bunch, Gilligan's Island), dies at 94

Alimuddin, Pakistani cricket batsman (25 Tests, 2 x 100s, 7 x 50s; Rajputana, Karachi), dies at 81

Alan Whicker, British journalist and TV broadcaster (Whicker's World), dies at 91

2013 Amar Bose, American electrical engineer, academic (M.I.T.), sound engineer, inventor, and entrepreneur (Bose Corporation), dies at 83

2013 Pran Krishan Sikand, Indian actor often cast as the villain in Hindi cinema (Khandaan, Be-Imaan), dies of pneumonia at 93

Kenneth J. Gray, American politician (Rep-D-IL, 1955-74, 85-89), dies at 89

2014 Pat Costello Jr., American rower (Olympics, 1952, silver - 1956), dies at 85

Gregg Smith, American choral conductor and composer, dies at 84

(Charles) "Chuck" Blazer, American soccer administrator, dies from colorectal cancer at 72

2017 Ray Phiri, South African jazz and mbaqanga guitarist (Paul Simon; Stimela), dies of cancer at 70

2017 Scharlette Holdman, American death penalty mitigation specialist, dies at 70

2017 Tommy Carberry, Irish jockey (Grand National 1975, Cheltenham Gold Cup 1970, 71 [L'Escargot]) and trainer (Grand National 1999 [Bobbyjo]), dies from a stroke at 75

Len Chappell, American basketball forward (NBA All-Star 1964 NY Knicks; All-American 1962 Wake Forest Uni), dies of stroke & pneumonia at 77

2018 Robert Wolders, Dutch actor (Erik Hunter-Laredo), dies at 81

2018 Tom Gallagher, American diplomat, gay activist, and 1st Foreign Service officer to publicly come out in 1976, dies at 77

2018 Wibo van de Linde, Dutch TV host, director, and screenwriter (Avro), dies at 79

Arno Marsh, American jazz saxophonist (Woody Herman), and bandleader, dies at 91

Judy Dyble, British folk singer-songwriter (Fairport Convention), dies of lung cancer at 71

2020 Kelly Preston, American actress (Mischief, Twins, A Tigers Tale), dies of breast cancer at 57

2020 Lajos Szűcs, Hungarian soccer defender (37 caps; Ferencváros, Honvéd FC; Hungarian Footballer of the Year 1976; Olympic gold 1968), dies at 76

2020 Rod Bernard, American "swamp pop" singer ("Allons Danser Colinda"), dies at 79 [1]

2020 Wim Suurbier, Dutch soccer right back (60 caps; Ajax 392 games) and manager (LA Heat, TB Rowdies), dies of a cerebral haemorrhage at 75

Edwin Edwards, American politician (Governor of Louisiana 1992-96), dies at 93

2021 John L. Rotz, American thoroughbred jockey (Preakness Stakes 1962; Belmont Stakes 1970; Racing Hall of Fame 1983), dies at 86

2021 Paul Orndorff, American pro wrestler (WWE Hall of Fame 2005; WCW World Tag Team C'ship [Paul Roma] 1995; "Mr Wonderful"), dies at 71

Bramwell Tovey, British conductor (Vancouver Symphony, 2000-18; NY Philharmonic Summer Series, 2004-14), and composer (Stream of Limelight), dies of sarcoma at 69

2022 Jan Wijn, Dutch classical pianist and pedagogue, dies at 88

André Watts, American-Hungarian concert pianist, and educator, dies of prostate cancer at 77 [1] [2]

(Antonia) "Tonke" Dragt, Dutch children's author (Towers of February), dies at 93

2024 Khalid "Billy" Ibadulla, Pakistani cricket batsman (4 Tests; 1 x 100, HS 166; Warwickshire, Otago) and broadcaster (TVNZ), dies at 88

2024 Ruth Westheimer (née Karola Ruth Siegel) German-American sex therapist and media personality (Dr Ruth), dies at 96 [1]

July 12 Highlights
